issue.title: Character following "[]" in scene2d labels has wrong width
issue.body: I wrote a [small reproduction class](https://gist.github.com/horse-mans/ebbb6739b2234460d07e) for this. Tested in libgdx 1.6.5 on OS X 10.10.5. The basic idea is that when using color markup in scene2d labels, the character immediately following the "pop color" control code, `[]`, either doesn't have its width set correctly, or is not offset the correct amount from the character before the control code. The problem isn't confined to fonts with fixed width glyphs specified, but it does help illustrate it better. The above code run with the call to `font.setFixedWidthGlyphs` commented out: Small but noticeable difference. This difference is more pronounced on monospace fonts (even with no fixed width glyphs specified). With the call uncommented: Note: 1. How more pronounced the effect is the more `[]` controls are in the string, and 2. The amount of space between the last 't' and the first period on each line. This may or may not be related to #3239, but my hunch is it's a different subtle bug somewhere else in the glyph width calculation :-)

issue.title: The Label issues
issue.body:
Hello, yesterday I've updated libgdx from 1.5.2 to 1.7.0 and have noticed some issues with scene2d.ui Labels.
## Issue 1

Maybe it's intended, maybe not. In 1.7.0 Labels don't have a little space before the first character (actually the part of this character) and after the last one.

Please, see this example. It's a Label added to a table cell. Compare its left and right boundaries as was in the version 1.5.2 and as is in the version 1.7.0.

![space](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10563821/10561560/54c44096-7536-11e5-8f26-c22ed42d8977.png)
## Issue 2 - really bizarre one

When you add a Label to a table cell and set the width of the latter, some characters may become broken...

Here is an example, where I have a table and add a lot of labels into its cells (like table.add(label).width(columnWidth)). Please, notice some strange artifacts in some characters (especially 'F', '5', '6'). The same thing without setting the width is below -- as you can see, all characters there are rendered correctly. Btw the font is 32px size and pregenerated with FreeTypeFontGenerator.

Please, click on the image to see it in full size.

![label_artifacts1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10563821/10561589/6325fcb8-7538-11e5-81cf-3f3c6d2040ce.png)

Another example is with a TextButton and its Label. When simply added to a table, the Label is rendered correctly, but if added followed by fillX(), the artifact appears:

![label_artifacts2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10563821/10561596/e24f3676-7538-11e5-8e6d-d30cd80aee5e.png)

The font is Lato 2.015 Light (Lato-Light.ttf):
http://www.latofonts.com

issue.title: Fix to set first and last glyphs in a glyph run to the correct width

body:
Thanks very much for the investigation and explanation, and apologies for the delay in replying.

The updated `getGlyphs` works for me. I see what you mean about the difficulty of a fix. Since `setFixedWidthGlyphs` takes a list of glyphs rather than fixed width being applied to the whole font, a `boolean fixedWidth` field in `Glyph` seems to make most sense. Also better to have to deal with a special case in a custom `getGlyphs` implementation than the more common case of using `setFixedWidthGlyphs`. See what you think of the pull request.
